Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: From advancing of theory of chemical bonding to advanced cluster-based materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Anastassia Alexandrova of the University of California - Los Angeles and her team are investigating the potential of sub-nano-sized clusters of platinum and palladium clusters, doped with other atoms, to be used as catalysts in chemical reactions. Catalysis is important to the chemical industry in providing efficient, low-energy methods for chemical synthesis. The young researchers working on this project will receive in-depth training in state-of-the art computational methods.

Professor Alexandrova and her research group will use first-principle calculations and multi-scale methods to probe the chemical bonding and reactivity in small transition metal clusters, both free and bound to surfaces. The results from this project will help develop a better understanding of any reactivity rules for these small clusters, guiding work of experimentalists in developing improved catalysts. Computational results for gas-phase clusters will be compared with experimental results. The computational methods should find applications in other condensed-phase systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

The project used computational techniques to develop the theory of chemical bonding for materials based on small clusters, i.e. assemblies of 3-10 atoms, with the goal of explaining and rationally predicting new material properties, as well as new functional materials. Several types of functional materials have been in focus: heterogeneous catalytic interfaces, ultra-hard alloys, alloys exhibiting quantum behavior (such as superconductivity), and artificial metalloenzymes featuring metal centers and clusters in their active sites for non-physiological catalysis. The project additionally developed multi-scale modeling methods to address these complicated systems in conditions of their practical use. Most projects involved collaboration with experiment, which tested theoretical predictions. For example, the project rationalized the extreme hardness of some transition metal borides through the details of the metal-boron bonding that the material can attain. This enabled further design of alloys with enhanced hardness. Chemical bonding was used to explain how mechanical stress can affect superconductivity, and predicted the type and strength of strain required for the onset of superconductivity in an otherwise not superconducting alloy. New 2-dimentional phases with unique electronic properties, such as anisotropic electric conductivity, were predicted. Catalytic surface alloys that prevent catalyst deactivation were designed. 

Broader impacts:

The project enabled education of graduate and undergraduate students, and postdocs in the field of computational and theoretical chemistry, in close connection with experimental partners. These trainees became the modern workforce for chemical and pharmaceutical industry, IT sector, National Labs, and academia. Among the trained students and postdocs, a large fraction came from underrepresented backgrounds in science. Research components and teaching were successfully integrated: in a computer laboratory course, Computational Methods for Chemists, developed by the PI, an optional final project was offered, which was a real open-ended research project. Students could participate in it using the computational tools that they just learned in class. On three occasions, these projects were so successful that they resulted in joint publications with the students, in leading peer reviewed journals. A summer school on computational chemistry, for mainly-Latino high school students from central Los Angeles, was run for several years in the PI’s laboratory. In this one-week school, students spent several hours per day on UCLA campus, used computational approaches to address some of the chemistry problems known to them from their class, under close supervision of the PI’s laboratory members, and connected with graduate and undergraduate students in UCLA.
